# Why R?

## Brief History

-   **1975-1976**: S (Book: [*A Brief History of S*](https://sas.uwaterloo.ca/~rwoldfor/software/R-code/historyOfS.pdf)) grew up in the statistics research departments at Bell Laboratories

    -   To bring interactive computing to bear on statistics and data analysis problem

## Example of S Language: the Subscripting Operator




::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
X = 1:5 # A vector of numbers from 1 to 5
X[c(TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[1:3]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[-1:3]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}

```
Error in X[-1:3]: only 0's may be mixed with negative subscripts
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[-(1:3)]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 4 5
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[NULL]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
integer(0)
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[NA]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] NA NA NA NA NA
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
X[]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```


:::
:::
